content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the most recent paper related to non-commutative geometry submitted by an author with the first name John. Provide the title and the abstract.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search arXiv for the most recent paper related to non-commutative geometry by an author named John, I should use the main search bar. I need to input keywords that include "non-commutative geometry" and "John" in the author field to improve relevance. The search textbox appears to be at element [4], and the search button is [8].
Action: Type [4]; non-commutative geometry author:John
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search failed because the query format was incorrect. The tips suggest using the Author(s) field directly (possibly from "All fields" dropdown) and following the "surname, forename" or "surname, initial" format. Next, I should use Advanced Search to specify "non-commutative geometry" and author as "John" in the recommended field for better accuracy.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query in the search term box is still incorrect. For advanced search, I need to separate the topic ("non-commutative geometry") and the author ("John") into their specific fields. I should clear the search term box and add search fields for "Title/Abstract" with "non-commutative geometry" and "Author(s)" with "John".
Action: Type [12]; non-commutative geometry
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search for "non-commutative geometry" alone still returned no results, likely because the author filter "John" has not yet been applied. I should go back to advanced search and use the option to "Add another term," entering "John" as the Author. This way, I can ensure the search addresses both the topic and the author.
Action: Click [12] (Refine query)
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to add another search term specifically for the author named "John." The "Add another term +" button [14] allows adding an author field to the advanced search. I will click this to add the author-specific search.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The advanced search now has a second search field, but it defaults to "Title." I need to change this to "Author(s)" and enter "John" to specify papers authored by someone with the first name John. I should interact with the dropdown menu [16] to change the field from "Title" to "Author(s)" before inputting the name.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the search field is open, and "Author(s)" is an available option. I need to select "Author(s)" to specify that the next search term will be the author's name.
Action: Click [16] (on "Author(s)")
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown on the second search term is open, but "Author(s)" has not been selected yet. I need to select "Author(s)" from the dropdown so I can specify "John" in the textbox.
Action: Click [16] ("Author(s)" option)
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown list is open on the second search field, showing multiple options. "Author(s)" is the target option and needs to be selected so the next input will be recognized as an author query.
Action: Click [16] (select "Author(s)" from the dropdown)
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: "Author(s)" is now selected as the field for the second term. I need to input "John" in the corresponding textbox ([15]) to filter for papers authored by someone named John.
Action: Type [15]; John
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query returned no results, likely because the author search was not formatted as "surname, forename" (e.g., "Smith, John"), or the query is too restrictive by specifying both the topic and "John" in this way. To broaden the search, I should try searching with the author field as "John" only and the topic in the title/abstract field, potentially using simpler keywords or only in the author field.
Action: Click [12] (Refine query)
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query fields are ready: the first term is "non-commutative geometry" and the second term is "John" as Author(s). The search fields and inputs seem correct now. The next step is to execute the search with the current setup using the Search button ([17]).
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.9

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: "order: -announced_date_first; size: 50; include_cross_list: True; terms: AND all=non-commutative geometryConfidence: 0.95; AND title=JohnConfidence: 0.99";	[12]: "Refine query";	[13]: "New search";	[14]: "Simple Search";	[15]: "About";	[16]: "Help";	[17]: "Contact";	[18]: "Subscribe";	[19]: "Copyright";	[20]: "Privacy Policy";	[21]: "Web Accessibility Assistance";	[22]: "arXiv Operational Status";	[23]: "email";	[24]: "slack";

content:
Thought: The query still returned no results. This could be because "John" is only the first name, and arXiv usually records authors as "Lastname, Firstname" or "Lastname, Initial." Searching for just "John" in author fields may not match the database format. For the next approach, I should broaden the search by using the main search box with just "non-commutative geometry John" in "All fields" to catch mentions in any context (title, abstract, author, etc.).
Action: Type [4]; non-commutative geometry John
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.92

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: <input> "";	[12]: "All fieldsTitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierDOIORCIDLicense (URI)arXiv author IDHelp pagesFull text";	[13]: <button> "Search";	[16]: "Advanced Search";	[17]: "Using the Author(s) field produces best results for author name searches.";	[18]: "For the most precise name search, follow surname(s), forename(s) or surname(s), initial(s) pattern: example Hawking, S or Hawking, Stephen";	[19]: "For best results on multiple author names, separate individuals with a ; (semicolon). Example: Jin, D S; Ye, J";	[20]: "Author names enclosed in quotes will return only exact matches. For example, "Stephen Hawking" will not return matches for Stephen W. Hawking.";	[21]: "Diacritic character variants are automatically searched in the Author(s) field.";

content:
Thought: The combined "non-commutative geometry John" query in all fields also returned no results. The tips shown indicate arXiv requires the author search in the "surname, forename" or "surname, initial" format, e.g., "Smith, John". Searching for just "John" is too broad or not matched in their author database. To proceed, I should try a more general search in the "All fields" for "non-commutative geometry" only to list recent papers, then look through author lists for one with first name John.
Action: Type [11]; non-commutative geometry
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.94

content:
Thought: The search for "non-commutative geometry" alone is still returning no results. This indicates there may be a spelling issue or too much specificity in the query. I should try alternative phrasings, such as "noncommutative geometry" (without the hyphen), as this is commonly used in mathematics and arXiv papers.
Action: Type [11]; noncommutative geometry
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.96
